item.title: 【Prometheus native histograms in Grafana Cloud: Get more precision from your Grafana visualizations】Grafana Cloud 中的 Prometheus 原生直方图：从 Grafana 可视化中获得更高的精度
item.description:
【

In May, we announced the public preview of Prometheus native histograms in Grafana Cloud, unlocking greater precision, ease of use, and compatibility for analyzing latency, duration, and other distributions. Since then, we’ve seen incredible adoption across industries—from financial services companies to e-commerce platforms. 

Last week, during PromCon EU 2025, the Prometheus developers announced that native histograms are now stable, after three years of intense testing and improvements. And today, we’re excited to share that Prometheus native histograms are also now generally available in Grafana Cloud!

Why customers chose native histograms

Compared to the classic Prometheus histograms, Prometheus native histograms—native histograms, for short—offer higher resolution and precision. They’re also easier to instrument and you can use them to combine and manipulate histograms in queries and in Grafana.

Plus, native histograms provide compatibility with other formats, such as OpenTelemetry exponential histograms and Datadog distributions.

During the public preview, our customers put native histograms in production-like scenarios. They found that traditional histograms, with their predefined bucket boundaries, often made it difficult to achieve the right level of precision. Native histograms solved this by dynamically adjusting buckets and efficiently capturing distributions.

Here’s what our customers told us:

  • A financial services customer utilized native histograms to dynamically configure histogram buckets, thereby reducing the operational and monetary costs associated with histograms.
  • An e-commerce platform onboarded dozens of internal teams without the need to configure the buckets manually each time. This has dramatically reduced the toil of manual onboarding and onboarded teams much faster. The customer also reduces the number of buckets by around 30% through a more efficient use of histograms. 

Note: Because native histograms are stable in Prometheus, that means they’re also stable in other downstream projects like Grafana Mimir.

What is new in GA

The biggest change since we first announced native histogram support is the direct integration with Grafana Metrics Drilldown, our popular queryless experience for browsing Prometheus-compatible metrics.

With instant access to the higher-resolution, more precise histogram data, the app automatically identifies native histogram metric types and generates the corresponding queries and visualizations, allowing you to view your data immediately without needing to write PromQL. 

This streamlined workflow enables you to visualize native histogram distributions immediately, while also comparing them side by side with classic histograms to understand the differences in resolution and accuracy. 

When you’re ready to dig deeper, simply select any native histogram metric and use the “Open in Explore” function to see the underlying PromQL functions, giving you a clear path from queryless exploration to advanced query customization.

Pricing

During the public preview, we found that our current pricing worked well for customers, and we intend to maintain this pricing structure going into GA.

If you haven’t used this feature yet, be aware that native histograms are billed differently from regular time series. A native histogram active series is equal to one active bucket multiplied by 0.25. We made this pricing change to pass on the resource savings to our customers. As a result, customers can leverage the high resolution from native histograms without worrying about cost. 

What’s next

We’re actively working on native histogram custom buckets (NHCB), which is an additional kind of native histogram for Prometheus that let users keep their existing histograms (no change to the instrumentation, only to the data collection) and store them in native histograms. 

The benefits include lower costs and increased reliability. We should note that NHCB depends on Prometheus Remote-Write 2.0, which is still experimental. NHCB also requires updates to queries the same way as other native histograms. We’ll share more documentation for using NHCB in Grafana Cloud in the future. 

We also plan to integrate native histograms directly with Grafana Cloud products like Application Observability and Frontend Observability, so that users will get more out-of-the-box experience across our cloud offerings.

And to get started with native histograms today, please refer to our documentation to learn more.

Grafana Cloud is the easiest way to get started with metrics, logs, traces, dashboards, and more. We have a generous forever-free tier and plans for every use case. Sign up for free now!

】

5 月份，我们宣布推出 Grafana Cloud 中 Prometheus 原生直方图的公开预览版，为分析延迟、持续时间和其他分布提供更高的精度、易用性和兼容性。从那时起，我们看到了从金融服务公司到电子商务平台等各个行业的令人难以置信的采用。 

上周，在 PromCon EU 2025 期间，Prometheus 开发人员宣布，经过三年的严格测试和改进，原生直方图现已稳定。今天，我们很高兴与大家分享，Prometheus 原生直方图现在也在 Grafana Cloud 中普遍可用！

为什么客户选择原生直方图

与经典的 Prometheus 直方图相比，Prometheus 原生直方图（简称原生直方图）提供了更高的分辨率和精度。它们也更容易检测，您可以使用它们在查询和 Grafana 中组合和操作直方图。

此外，本机直方图还提供与其他格式的兼容性，例如 OpenTelemetry 指数直方图和 Datadog 分布。

在公共预览期间，我们的客户将本机直方图放入类似生产的场景中。他们发现传统的直方图及其预定义的桶边界通常很难达到正确的精度水平。本机直方图通过动态调整存储桶并有效捕获分布来解决这个问题。

以下是我们的客户告诉我们的内容：

  • 金融服务客户利用原生直方图动态配置直方图存储桶，从而降低与直方图相关的运营和资金成本。
  • 一个电子商务平台加入了数十个内部团队，而无需每次都手动配置存储桶。这极大地减少了手动入职的工作量，并且更快地入职团队。客户还通过更有效地使用直方图，将存储桶数量减少了约 30%。 
<块引用>

注意：由于原生直方图在 Prometheus 中稳定，这意味着它们在其他下游项目中也稳定，例如 Grafana Mimir。

GA 中的新功能

自我们首次宣布原生直方图支持以来最大的变化是与 Grafana Metrics Drilldown 的直接集成，这是我们用于浏览 Prometheus 兼容指标的流行无查询体验。

即时访问更高分辨率、更精确的直方图数据时，应用程序会自动识别本机直方图指标类型并生成相应的查询和可视化，使您无需编写 PromQL 即可立即查看数据。 

这种简化的工作流程使您能够立即可视化本机直方图分布，同时还将它们与经典直方图并排进行比较，以了解分辨率和准确性的差异。 

<图 类=“图包装图包装__lightbox w-100p” 样式=“最大宽度：无；” itemprop =“关联媒体” 项目范围=“” itemtype =“http://schema.org/ImageObject” ><一个 类=“灯箱链接” href="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/977x279/ca0d0f1a9e/native-histogram-compare.png/m/" itemprop=“内容网址” >
<无脚本> <图片 src =“https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/977x279/ca0d0f1a9e/native-histogram-compare.png/m/” alt="两个 Grafana 热图显示 HTTP 请求持续时间随时间的变化，颜色渐变指示不同的持续时间和强度级别。"/>

当您准备好深入挖掘时，只需选择任何本机直方图指标并使用“在探索中打开”功能即可查看底层 PromQL 函数，为您提供从无查询探索到高级查询自定义的清晰路径。

定价

在公开预览期间，我们发现我们当前的定价对客户来说效果很好，我们打算在正式发布后保持这种定价结构。

如果您尚未使用此功能，请注意本机直方图的计费方式与常规时间序列不同。本机直方图活动系列等于一个活动存储桶乘以 0.25。我们做出此定价调整是为了将资源节省惠及我们的客户。因此，客户可以利用原生直方图的高分辨率，而无需担心成本。 

下一步是什么

我们正在积极开发原生直方图自定义存储桶 (NHCB)，这是 Prometheus 的另一种原生直方图，它允许用户保留现有直方图（不更改仪器，仅更改数据收集）并将其存储在原生直方图中。 

好处包括降低成本和提高可靠性。我们应该注意的是，NHCB 依赖于 Prometheus Remote-Write 2.0，该版本仍处于实验阶段。 NHCB 还需要像其他本机直方图一样更新查询。将来我们将分享更多在 Grafana Cloud 中使用 NHCB 的文档是的。 

我们还计划将原生直方图直接与 Grafana Cloud 产品（例如应用程序可观察性和前端可观察性）集成，以便用户在我们的云产品中获得更多开箱即用的体验。

要立即开始使用原生直方图，请参阅我们的文档了解更多信息。

Grafana Cloud 是开始使用指标、日志、跟踪、仪表板等的最简单方法。我们为每个用例提供慷慨的永久免费套餐和计划。 立即免费注册！

item.title: 【SQL expressions in Grafana: Combine and manipulate data from multiple sources】Grafana 中的 SQL 表达式：组合和操作来自多个源的数据
item.description:
【

One of Grafana’s greatest strengths is its ability to provide a consistent monitoring experience for all your data sources. But not everyone wants to go through the process of transforming that data and setting up a data warehouse to make that happen, especially for complex analyses. 

That’s why we developed  SQL expressions, a Grafana feature that lets you manipulate and combine data from different data sources—Prometheus, MySQL, BigQuery, Grafana Loki, Google Sheets, and more—as if they were all tables in the same MySQL database. 

This new feature, currently in public preview in Grafana OSS, Grafana Enterprise, and Grafana Cloud, can be used with dashboard panels as well Grafana-managed alerting and recording rules. This makes SQL expressions a versatile and powerful feature that opens up all sorts of creative possibilities.

And with the Grafana LLM plugin (not to be confused with Grafana Assistant), you can even write SQL queries using natural language—so the power of SQL is accessible even if you aren’t fluent in it.

The possibilities are wide open, but here are a few ways to start imagining what’s possible.

Enhance a single data source

The simplest use case is to take data from a single source—whether it’s tabular data (like MySQL) or time series data (like Prometheus)—and treat it as a table.

Once you have that, you can:

  • Aggregate, filter, and perform math operations
  • Smooth noisy time series
  • Generate regression or trend lines
  • Compute projections (like “time to threshold”)
  • Build alerts on top of derived values

For example, with just one expression you can smooth a metric, fit a trend line, calculate the predicted time to reach a threshold, visualize it, and alert when that time is below a limit.

Combine data source responses

SQL expressions can join different data source types at the same time. So you can connect completely different systems in a single query. This opens the door to combining data that’s spread across many systems, which widens the possibilities of Grafana’s “big tent” philosophy.

That means you can correlate Prometheus metrics with MySQL tables, and/or join Microsoft Azure data with Google Sheets—directly in Grafana, no data warehouse required.

This is especially powerful when some of your data lives in systems you can’t or don’t want to centralize. Many organizations have 80%–90% of their data in a warehouse but still rely on other operational systems. SQL expressions let you bridge that last gap, ad hoc, without waiting on ETL pipelines.

Using natural language

And since not everyone is an expert in SQL, we’re integrating SQL expressions with the Grafana LLM plugin to provide AI-powered assistance in your workflow. Once you’ve installed the plugin, which is currently in public preview, you can use it to get a detailed explanation of your query. You can also receive suggestions for performance and reliability enhancements, column naming best practices, and guidance on panel optimization. 

The suggestions will be saved (from newest to oldest) for quick access and to create a history of improvements. And if your query has a parsing error, such as a syntax issue, the LLM can automatically identify errors and help you rewrite the query correctly.

More ideas to explore

Looking for more ways to use SQL expressions? Here are just a few other options to help you get started: 

  • GitHub + Sheets + Prometheus: Join PR and issue data from GitHub with team ownership data in Google Sheets and service reliability metrics from Prometheus, then build dashboards that show engineering throughput and service health side-by-side.
  • Threshold tables for alerting: Define custom thresholds per cluster or service in a SQL data source, then join that with live metrics from Loki or Prometheus. Your alerting logic stays flexible and data-driven—not hard-coded in expressions.
  • SQL inception: Create recording rules, then query those metrics in Prometheus, and if you like, run SQL expressions on the metrics that were created by SQL expressions.

What’s next?

We’re excited for the community to start exploring SQL expressions, but we aren’t done yet. We’re exploring future capabilities like:

  • Support for more data source types
  • A better UI for knowing what the virtual SQL schema is
  • Chaining SQL expressions together so you can build dashboards the reference different parts of a data processing pipeline
  • Extending SQL expressions with custom functions

We can’t wait to see all the ways the community puts this new feature to use. If you have any questions or want to share feedback, please share it in this Google Form. 

Thank you to Dolthub

The central component of SQL expressions is go-mysql-server from Dolthub. Since the project is written in Go, we can use it without having to insert the data into another database first. It also helps us operationally, since we use Go in our stack and it aligns with general engineering expertise at Grafana Labs. Plus, the Dolthub community has also been very quick to respond and fix any issues we’ve reported.

 You can learn more about this on their blog.

Grafana Cloud is the easiest way to get started with metrics, logs, traces, dashboards, and more. We have a generous forever-free tier and plans for every use case. Sign up for free now!

】

Grafana 的最大优势之一是能够为所有数据源提供一致的监控体验。但并不是每个人都希望经历转换数据并建立数据仓库来实现这一目标的过程，尤其是对于复杂的分析。 

这就是我们开发 SQL 表达式的原因，这是一项 Grafana 功能，可让您操作和组合来自不同数据源（Prometheus、MySQL、BigQuery、Grafana Loki、Google Sheets 等）的数据，就好像它们都是同一 MySQL 数据库中的表一样。 

这项新功能目前在 Grafana OSS、Grafana Enterprise 和 Grafana Cloud 中提供公开预览版，还可与仪表板面板以及Grafana 管理的警报和记录规则。这使得 SQL 表达式成为一种多功能且强大的功能，开启了各种创造性的可能性。

借助 Grafana LLM 插件（不要与 Grafana Assistant 混淆），您甚至可以使用自然语言编写 SQL 查询，因此可以使用 SQL 的强大功能即使您不熟悉它。

可能性是广阔的，但这里有一些方法可以让你开始想象什么是可能的。

增强单个数据源

最简单的用例是从单一来源获取数据 - 无论是表格数据（如 MySQL）还是时间序列数据（如 Prometheus） - 并将其视为表格。

一旦你有了它，你就可以：

  • 聚合、过滤和执行数学运算
  • 平滑的噪声时间序列
  • 生成回归线或趋势线
  • 计算预测（例如“达到阈值的时间”）
  • 根据派生值构建提醒

例如，只需一个表达式，您就可以平滑指标、拟合趋势线、计算达到阈值的预测时间、将其可视化，并在该时间低于限制时发出警报。

合并数据源响应

SQL表达式可以同时连接不同的数据源类型。因此，您可以在单个查询中连接完全不同的系统。这为整合分布在多个系统中的数据打开了大门，从而扩大了 Grafana 的“大帐篷”的可能性哦；哲学。

这意味着您可以直接在 Grafana 中将 Prometheus 指标与 MySQL 表关联起来，和/或将 Microsoft Azure 数据与 Google Sheets 关联起来，无需数据仓库。

当您的某些数据位于您无法或不想集中的系统中时，此功能尤其强大。许多组织将 80%–90% 的数据存储在仓库中，但仍然依赖其他操作系统。 SQL 表达式让您可以临时弥补最后的差距，而无需等待 ETL 管道。

使用自然语言

由于并非每个人都是 SQL 专家，因此我们将 SQL 表达式与 Grafana LLM 插件集成，以便在您的工作流程中提供人工智能支持的帮助。安装该插件（目前处于公共预览版）后，您可以使用它来获取查询的详细解释。您还可以收到有关性能和可靠性增强的建议、列命名最佳实践以及面板优化指南。  <图 类=“图包装图包装__lightbox w-100p” 样式=“最大宽度：无；” itemprop =“关联媒体” 项目范围=“” itemtype =“http://schema.org/ImageObject” ><一个 类=“灯箱链接” href="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/872x381/e5216e756f/sqlexpressions-llm-integration-2.png/m/" itemprop=“内容网址” >

<无脚本> <图片 src =“https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/872x381/e5216e756f/sqlexpressions-llm-integration-2.png/m/” alt="Grafana 中的 SQL 表达式查询界面，突出显示“解释查询”和“改进查询”按钮"/>
这些建议将被保存（从最新到最旧），以便快速访问并创建改进历史记录。如果您的查询存在解析错误，例如语法问题，LLM 可以自动识别错误并帮助您正确重写查询。

更多想法可供探索

正在寻找更多使用 SQL 表达式的方法？以下是一些可帮助您入门的其他选项：

  • GitHub + Sheets + Prometheus：将 GitHub 中的 PR 和问题数据与 Google Sheets 中的团队所有权数据以及 Prometheus 中的服务可靠性指标结合起来，然后构建并排显示工程吞吐量和服务运行状况的仪表板。
  • 警报阈值表：在 SQL 数据源中定义每个集群或服务的自定义阈值，然后将其与 Loki 或 Prometheus 的实时指标结合起来。您的警报逻辑保持灵活且由数据驱动，而不是在表达式中硬编码。
  • SQL 启动：创建记录规则，然后在 Prometheus 中查询这些指标，如果您愿意，还可以对 SQL 表达式创建的指标运行 SQL 表达式。

下一步是什么？

我们很高兴社区开始探索 SQL 表达式，但我们还没有完成。我们正在探索未来的功能，例如：

  • 支持更多数据源类型
  • 更好的 UI，可让您了解虚拟 SQL 架构
  • 将 SQL 表达式链接在一起，以便您可以构建参考数据处理管道的不同部分的仪表板
  • 使用自定义函数扩展 SQL 表达式

我们迫不及待地想看看社区如何使用这一新功能。如果您有任何疑问或想要分享反馈，请在此 Google 表单中分享。 

感谢 Dolthub

SQL 表达式的核心组件是来自 Dolthub 的 go-mysql-server。由于该项目是用Go编写的，因此我们可以使用它而无需先将数据插入到另一个数据库中。它还在操作上帮助我们，因为我们在堆栈中使用 Go，并且它与 Grafana Labs 的一般工程专业知识相一致。此外，Dolthub 社区也非常迅速地响应并修复了我们报告的任何问题。

 您可以在他们的博客上了解更多相关信息。

Grafana Cloud 是开始使用指标、日志、跟踪、仪表板等的最简单方法。我们为每个用例提供慷慨的永久免费套餐和计划。 立即免费注册！

item.title: 【Grafana Labs at KubeCon: OpenTelemetry eBPF Instrumentation, Prometheus deep dives, and more】KubeCon 上的 Grafana 实验室：OpenTelemetry eBPF 仪器、Prometheus 深入研究等
item.description:
【

KubeCon + CloudNativeCon North America 2025 is right around the corner — and we can’t wait to see you there! 

The event will run from November 10-13 in Atlanta, Georgia, bringing together open source enthusiasts for the Cloud Native Computing Foundation’s flagship conference. And this year’s event is a particularly special one, marking the CNCF’s 10-year anniversary.

Grafana Labs is a proud silver sponsor of KubeCon North America 2025, including Observability Day 2025.

If you plan to attend, drop by booth #444 (hall B3) at KubeCon’s sponsor solutions showcase to meet the team and grab some swag (because who wouldn’t want a sweet sticker of Grot holding a Georgia peach?!).

You can also contact us to set up a meeting with one of our experts, or attend one of the sessions we’re participating in (more on that below).

KubeCon sessions featuring Grafana Labs

The following KubeCon North America talks (all times local) feature, or are led by, members of the Grafana Labs team:

Telemetry that matches your model, verified live

Monday, November 10 • 10:40am - 11:05am EST 

OpenTelemetry semantic conventions define how telemetry should look, but do instrumentations actually follow them in practice? Your organization might define additional conventions — but how do you ensure instrumentations stay up to date as conventions evolve?

What if you could get a comprehensive report on the actual telemetry your application produces, checked against your conventions model?

In this session, Liudmila Molkova, Staff Developer Advocate at Grafana Labs, and Jeremy Blythe, VP Engineering at Evertz, share OpenTelemetry Weaver’s live check: a validation tool that listens to telemetry in real time and analyzes its compatibility against formally defined conventions. They’ll show you how to run live checks in your CI/CD pipelines to catch instrumentation issues before they hit production — no more guessing whether your telemetry matches your model.

Beyond basic model compliance, the speakers will also demonstrate how to write Rego policies to enforce organization-specific checks and best practices.

Straight into the deep end! Learning Kubernetes and cloud native from scratch in late 2024

Tuesday, November 11 • 5:45pm - 6:15pm EST 

Many people attending KubeCon have spent years on both cloud native and Kubernetes — growing in their technical knowledge alongside the development of these concepts and technologies.

But, for others, this isn’t the case. There are those who are just starting out their careers. And there are others who pivoted from industries that used older methods, tools, and technologies.

This talk, led by Grafana Labs Senior Principal Field Engineer Éamon Ryan and Senior Field Engineer Ayah Elshaikh, aims to take those very people through what it’s like to dive head-first into Kubernetes and cloud native in the modern day through the eyes of an engineer who did exactly that just recently — learning it in its mature form instead of iteratively along with it. It discusses the challenges and pitfalls that can be overcome or avoided.

Additionally, the session covers what’s changed in those years that has made things easier, from the alternate perspective of an engineer who has been using Kubernetes for many years.

UX Research Report: Prometheus and OTel’s resources attributes

Wednesday, November 12 • 2:15pm - 2:45pm EST 

Prometheus and OpenTelemetry are two CNCF projects that focus on observability and truly excel at their main purposes. However, it’s no secret that they started their integration journey on the wrong foot. This story is getting better over time and being done in a data-driven way!

Through CNCF’s LFX mentorship program, the presenters of this talk — Victoria Nduka, User Experience Designer, Independent and Amy Super, Principal Product Designer, Grafana Labs — conducted UX Research to understand how Prometheus should handle OTel’s resource attributes. Using quantitative and qualitative approaches, they collected opinions from co-founders of both projects, active and old maintainers, and several end users.

By joining this talk, you’ll learn more about what is going well and what could be improved, while listening to Victoria and Amy’s educated suggestions for the project maintainers.

Debugging your cluster when it’s on fire

Wednesday, November 12 • 4:00pm - 4:25pm EST 

Imagine you have a Kubernetes cluster that’s hosting some number of services. Perhaps these services are written in different programming languages, and perhaps there are some databases in the cluster, too. Now imagine that this cluster is intermittently experiencing errors and it’s not easy to tell what’s going on.

In this talk, Nikola Grcevski, Principal Software Engineer at Grafana Labs, and Tyler Yahn, Senior Software Engineer at Splunk, will show you how you can add detailed telemetry immediately to a problematic production environment cluster, without any changes to your existing cluster configuration or applications, with the new OpenTelemetry eBPF Instrumentation project. They’ll show you how you’ll be able to get insights into what’s wrong with your cluster or services by leveraging on-demand distributed traces and connectivity graphs, even if it’s the first time you have heard the term OpenTelemetry.

They’ll also discuss the design principles that make this technology safe to deploy in an already problematic environment, without further compromising the stability of your cluster.

Observing dark matter with OpenTelemetry

Wednesday, November 12 • 5:30pm - 6:00pm EST 

Stories of time wasted (and lots of emotions). What time do we really measure when we instrument our applications and try to collect request duration times? What conclusions do we draw when the request duration reported by client requests doesn’t even come close to the times reported by the server? Do we blame our network, our reverse proxies, or our monitoring tools when “dark matter” gaps exist in our traces?

This talk, led by Mario Macías, Staff Software Engineer at Grafana Labs, and Sam Alipio, Staff Product Manager at Pasteur Labs, covers some subtle nuances in request duration measurement, which can often lead to completely misleading results. They’ll dig deep into the OpenTelemetry instrumentation approaches in a few popular programming languages and correlate what the duration timings in traces or logs mean.

They’ll show how using the newly donated OpenTelemetry eBPF Instrumentation for application instrumentation allows you to augment your telemetry to overcome various inaccuracies in duration measurement… and get closer to the truth.

Prometheus intro, deep dive, and open Q+A 

Thursday, November 13 • 1:45pm - 2:15pm EST  

As the second oldest project in the CNCF, Prometheus is probably something you’ve heard of before. Nevertheless, in this talk, Owen Williams — Prometheus project maintainer and Principal Software Engineer Grafana Labs — will give you an introduction from the very beginning, followed by a deep dive into the exciting new features that have been released recently or are in the pipeline. You will learn about many opportunities to use Prometheus, and maybe even be tempted to contribute to the project yourself.

】

KubeCon + CloudNativeCon 北美 2025 即将到来 - 我们迫不及待地想在那里见到您！ 

该活动将于 11 月 10 日至 13 日在佐治亚州亚特兰大举行，云原生计算基金会旗舰会议的开源爱好者将齐聚一堂。今年的活动尤为特别，标志着 CNCF 成立 10 周年。周年纪念日。

Grafana Labs 是 KubeCon North America 2025 的自豪的银牌赞助商，包括2025 年可观测日。

如果您打算参加，请前往 KubeCon 赞助商解决方案展示厅的 444 号展位（B3 厅）与团队见面并获取一些小礼物（因为谁不想要一张 Grot 拿着佐治亚桃子的甜蜜贴纸？！）。

<图 类=“图包装图包装__lightbox w-100p” 样式=“最大宽度：无；” itemprop =“关联媒体” 项目范围=“” itemtype =“http://schema.org/ImageObject” ><一个 类=“灯箱链接” href="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/317x351/468719cf46/grot-sticker-kubecon2025_3.png/m/" itemprop=“内容网址” >
<无脚本> <图片 src="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/317x351/468719cf46/grot-sticker-kubecon2025_3.png/m/" alt="Grot 的图像，Grafana 实验室吉祥物，拿着一个桃子。下面的文字为“KubeCon 2025”。"/>

您还可以联系我们安排与我们的一位专家举行会议，或参加我们正在参加的其中一场会议（更多内容请参见下文）。

以 Grafana Labs 为特色的 KubeCon 会议

以下 KubeCon 北美演讲（所有时间均为本地）以 Grafana Labs 团队成员为特色或由 Grafana Labs 团队成员主持：

与您的遥测数据相匹配模型，实时验证

11 月 10 日星期一 • 上午 10:40 - 上午 11:05美国东部时间 

OpenTelemetry 语义约定定义了遥测技术的外观，但仪器在实践中是否真正遵循它们？您的组织可能会定义其他约定 - 但如何确保工具随着约定的发展而保持最新状态？

如果您可以获得有关您的应用程序生成的实际遥测数据的综合报告，并根据您的约定模型进行检查，结果会怎样？

在本次会议中，Grafana Labs 的开发人员倡导者 Liudmila Molkova 和 Evertz 的工程副总裁 Jeremy Blythe 分享了 OpenTelemetry Weaver 的实时检查：一种验证工具，可以实时侦听遥测数据并分析其与正式定义约定的兼容性。他们将向您展示如何在 CI/CD 管道中运行实时检查，以便在投入生产之前捕获仪器问题 - 不再猜测您的遥测数据是否与您的模型匹配。

除了基本模型合规性之外，演讲者还将演示如何编写 Rego 策略来执行组织特定的检查和最佳实践。

直接进入深渊！ 2024 年末从头开始学习 Kubernetes 和云原生

11 月 11 日星期二 • 下午 5:45 - 6:15（美国东部时间） 

许多参加 KubeCon 的人都在云原生和 Kubernetes 上花费了数年时间，随着这些概念和技术的发展，他们的技术知识也不断增长。

但是，对于其他人来说，情况并非如此。有些人刚刚开始他们的职业生涯。还有一些人从使用旧方法、工具和技术的行业转向。

本次演讲由 Grafana Labs 高级首席现场工程师 Éamon Ryan 和高级现场工程师 Ayah Elshaikh 主持，旨在通过一位最近刚刚这样做的工程师的眼睛，带领这些人体验一下在现代深入研究 Kubernetes 和云原生的感觉 - 以成熟的形式学习它，而不是与之一起迭代。它讨论了可以克服或避免的挑战和陷阱。

此外，本次会议还介绍了这些年来发生的变化，这些变化使事情变得更加容易，从使用 Kubernetes 多年的工程师的另一个角度来看。

UX 研究报告：Prometheus 和 OTel 的资源属性

11 月 12 日星期三 • 下午 2:15 - 2:45（美国东部时间） 

Prometheus 和 OpenTelemetry 是两个 CNCF 项目，专注于可观察性并真正擅长实现其主要目的。然而，众所周知，他们的整合之旅一开始就走错了路。随着时间的推移，这个故事变得越来越好，并且是以数据驱动的方式完成的！

通过 CNCF 的 LFX 指导计划，本次演讲的演讲者 — Independent 用户体验设计师 Victoria Nduka 和 Grafana Labs 首席产品设计师 Amy Super — 进行了 UX 研究，以了解 Prometheus 应如何处理 OTel 的 资源属性。他们使用定量和定性的方法，收集了两个项目的联合创始人、活跃和老维护者以及一些最终用户的意见。

通过参加本次演讲，您将了解更多有关哪些方面进展顺利以及哪些方面可以改进的信息，同时聆听 Victoria 和 Amy 对项目维护人员提出的有根据的建议。

在以下情况下调试集群着火了

11 月 12 日星期三 • 下午 4:00 - 4:25（美国东部时间） 

假设您有一个托管一定数量服务的 Kubernetes 集群。也许这些服务是用不同的编程语言编写的，也许集群中也有一些数据库。现在想象一下这个集群间歇性地遇到错误，并且很难判断发生了什么。

在本次演讲中，Grafana Labs 首席软件工程师 Nikola Grcevski 和 Splunk 高级软件工程师 Tyler Yahn 将向您展示如何使用新的 OpenTelemetry eBPF 立即向有问题的生产环境集群添加详细的遥测数据，而无需对现有集群配置或应用程序进行任何更改仪器仪表项目。他们将向您展示如何通过利用按需分布式跟踪和连接图来深入了解集群或服务的问题，即使这是您第一次听说 OpenTelemetry 一词。

他们还将讨论设计原则，使该技术能够安全地部署在已经存在问题的环境中，而不会进一步损害集群的稳定性。

利用 OpenTelemetry 观测暗物质

11 月 12 日星期三 • 下午 5:30 - 6:00（美国东部标准时间） 

浪费时间（以及大量情感）的故事。当我们检测应用程序并尝试收集请求持续时间时，我们真正测量的时间是什么？当客户端请求报告的请求持续时间甚至不接近服务器报告的时间时，我们得出什么结论？当我们的痕迹中存在“暗物质”间隙时，我们是否会责怪我们的网络、反向代理或监控工具？

本次演讲由 Grafana Labs 的软件工程师 Mario Macías 和 Pasteur Labs 的产品经理 Sam Alipio 主持，涵盖了请求持续时间测量中的一些细微差别，这些细微差别通常会导致完全误导的结果。他们将深入研究几种流行编程语言中的 OpenTelemetry 检测方法，并将跟踪或日志中的持续时间计时的含义关联起来。

他们将展示如何使用新捐赠的 OpenTelemetry eBPF Instrumentation 进行应用程序检测，让您能够增强遥测技术，以克服持续时间测量中的各种不准确性……并更接近事实。

普罗米修斯简介、深入探讨和开放式问答 

11 月 13 日星期四 • 下午 1:45 - 2:15（美国东部时间）  

作为 CNCF 中第二古老的项目，Prometheus 可能您以前听说过。尽管如此，在本次演讲中，Prometheus 项目维护者兼 Grafana Labs 首席软件工程师 Owen Williams 将从头开始向您进行介绍，然后深入探讨最近发布或正在酝酿的令人兴奋的新功能。您将了解许多使用 Prometheus 的机会，甚至可能会想自己为该项目做出贡献。

item.title: 【Faster, more collaborative data exploration: Introducing saved queries in Grafana Cloud】更快、更具协作性的数据探索：在 Grafana Cloud 中引入保存的查询
item.description:
【

Writing queries is one of Grafana’s most powerful features, but it can also be one of the most time-consuming. Whether you’re exploring logs or building new dashboards, you often find yourself and your team rewriting the same queries over and over again.

This is why we rolled out saved queries, a feature that makes it easy for everyone on your team to save, share, and reuse queries, eliminating the need to start from scratch each time. This helps new team members get up to speed faster, and allows your entire organization to benefit from consistent, well-crafted queries that reflect shared best practices.

Read on to learn how to get started with saved queries in Grafana Cloud, and check out a demo of the feature in the video below.

Why we built saved queries

For growing engineering teams, scalability is key to success. When working with Grafana Cloud, practices like metric standardization and reusable query components play a crucial role in helping teams efficiently scale their observability strategies.

Through conversations with our users, we noticed how they share knowledge across different stages of their observability workflows — from building dashboards to creating alert rules and troubleshooting issues. A common theme emerged: users wanted an easier way to reuse queries directly in Grafana Explore, without having to rewrite them from scratch or hunt for the right dashboard. Explore is often the natural entry point for users investigating logs or metrics, so this friction slowed them down.

Another recurring challenge has been onboarding new team members to Grafana Cloud. In many organizations, query knowledge is concentrated among early adopters or admins. Some teams have tried to bridge this gap by manually maintaining collections of reusable queries, but this approach didn’t scale.

We built saved queries to address these needs, and help teams capture, share, and reuse knowledge seamlessly, so they can get value from Grafana Cloud faster and at scale. Here’s a closer look at some of the key benefits and use cases.  

Standardize observability methodologies

Teams often rely on well-known frameworks like RED (Rate, Errors, Duration) or USE (Utilization, Saturation, Errors) to monitor system health. With saved queries, you can lock in consistent definitions for these key metrics across all your dashboards and alerts.

For example, you could save a consistent set of RED queries for all services, such as:

  • rate(http_requests_total[5m]) for request rate
  • rate(http_requests_errors_total[5m]) for error rate
  • histogram_quantile(0.95, sum(rate(http_request_duration_seconds_bucket[5m])) by (le)) for latency

Infrastructure teams relying on the USE method could save baseline queries for node or container metrics for more consistent resource analysis.

Build dashboards faster

Traditionally, building a Grafana dashboard has typically meant writing a new query for each panel. Now, with saved queries, you can pull from a library of reusable queries and quickly populate panels so you spend more time visualizing data and less time writing code.

For example, teams can create a “baseline query library” for metrics like request throughput, error counts, or cache hit ratio. When creating dashboards, users can simply pick from these trusted queries. Performance teams can also curate a list of “approved queries” that standardize how latency, availability, or resource usage are calculated across teams, reducing mismatched definitions.

Improve onboarding and knowledge sharing

Not everyone is an expert in query languages. For example, teams writing Grafana Loki queries in Explore often have to write complex LogQL expressions involving labels, regex filters, and rate functions. 

With saved queries, power users can save their well-tested LogQL queries, such as those for error rate per service or slow request logs, so others can reuse them without needing to learn LogQL as deeply.

This kind of knowledge sharing can also benefit troubleshooting workflows. When an incident occurs, responders can simply open Explore and reuse saved queries from past investigations to speed up response time.

Manage annotations  

In Grafana, annotations are a way to indicate certain events, including deployments, feature releases, or incident start/end times, within your visualizations. With saved queries, annotations become easier to manage and reuse. 

Instead of manually recreating annotation queries on every dashboard, teams can save a single query — for example, a Loki LogQL expression like {app="frontend", message=~"Deployment.*completed"} to mark deployments, or a PromQL query that pulls incident timestamps from metrics — and reuse it across dashboards. This ensures consistent event overlays such as deploys, outages, or config changes, while simplifying setup for non-experts and reducing maintenance overhead.

Reduce costly mistakes

Accidentally writing an expensive or inefficient query can slow things down and impact the bottom line. Saved queries allows query language experts to provide trusted, optimized queries that others can safely reuse. This reduces risk and helps teams maintain consistent query performance across dashboards and Explore sessions.

Get started with saved queries

There are two main ways to interact with the saved queries feature: saving a query, or using a saved query. 

How to save a query

When you create a query in the query editor that you want to save, click Save query. 

This opens the saved queries drawer, where you can enter a title, optional description, and tags for your query.

Tags and a detailed description are helpful to group queries based on meaningful themes for your organization. This makes it easy for others to find queries that are relevant to them via a searchable list.

You can also choose between two visibility options for your query:

  • Private: This is the default setting, and means the query will only be visible to you.
  • Shared: Use this setting when you want to make the query visible to other users across your organization.

How to use a saved a query 

To access other queries that your teammates have saved, click + Add from saved queries in the query editor.

This, again, will open the saved queries drawer, where you can search and filter queries by data source, author, or tags.

Note that when you add a saved query to a panel or Explore, the query content is automatically copied in; if the author of that query eventually makes edits to it, you’ll need to re-add the query.

You can also create a list of queries you refer back to most often, and quickly find them in the Favorites tab.

Wrapping up

Saved queries is available in public preview today for all Grafana Cloud users, and can also be enabled in Grafana Enterprise via the queryLibrary feature toggle. To learn more about how to save, share, and manage your queries, please check out our documentation.

Looking ahead, we’re exploring ways to make saved queries even more powerful, including enhanced support for parametrized queries, support for alert rules, and the ability to store queries by reference, so a single change can automatically update every dashboard that uses it.

In the meantime, we’d love to hear your thoughts as you start using saved queries. Please fill out the feedback form in the saved queries drawer to share what you like and what we can improve. Your feedback will help shape the future of this feature!

Grafana Cloud is the easiest way to get started with metrics, logs, traces, dashboards, and more. We have a generous forever-free tier and plans for every use case. Sign up for free now!

】

编写查询是 Grafana 最强大的功能之一，但它也可能是最耗时的功能之一。无论您是在探索日志还是构建新的仪表板，您经常会发现自己和您的团队一遍又一遍地重写相同的查询。

这就是我们推出已保存查询的原因，该功能使团队中的每个人都可以轻松保存、共享和重复使用查询，而无需每次都从头开始。这有助于新团队成员更快地掌握最新情况，并让您的整个组织能够从反映共享最佳实践的一致、精心设计的查询中受益。

继续阅读，了解如何开始使用 Grafana Cloud 中保存的查询，并观看下面视频中的功能演示。

我们为何构建已保存的查询

对于不断壮大的工程团队来说，可扩展性是成功的关键。使用 Grafana Cloud 时，指标标准化和可重用查询组件等实践在帮助团队有效扩展其可观察性策略方面发挥着至关重要的作用。

通过与用户的对话，我们注意到他们如何在可观察性工作流程的不同阶段分享知识 - 从构建仪表板到创建警报规则和问题排查。出现了一个共同的主题：用户希望有一种更简单的方法可以直接在 Grafana Explore 中重用查询，而无需从头开始重写或寻找正确的仪表板。探索通常是用户调查日志或指标的自然切入点，因此这种摩擦减慢了他们的速度。

另一个经常出现的挑战是让新团队成员加入 Grafana Cloud。在许多组织中，查询知识集中在早期采用者或管理员手中。一些团队尝试通过手动维护可重用查询的集合来弥补这一差距，但这种方法无法扩展。

我们构建了已保存的查询来满足这些需求，并帮助团队无缝捕获、共享和重用知识，以便他们可以更快、更大规模地从 Grafana Cloud 获取价值。以下是一些主要优势和用例的详细介绍。  

标准化可观测性方法

团队经常依赖众所周知的框架，例如RED （速率、错误、持续时间） 或 使用 （利用率、饱和度、错误） 通过保存的查询，您可以在所有仪表板和警报中锁定这些关键指标的一致定义。

例如，您可以为所有服务保存一组一致的 RED 查询，例如：

  • rate(http_requests_total[5m]) 请求率
  • rate(http_requests_errors_total[5m]) 错误率
  • histogram_quantile(0.95, sum(rate(http_request_duration_seconds_bucket[5m])) by (le)) 延迟

依赖 USE 方法的基础设施团队可以保存节点或容器指标的基线查询，以实现更一致的资源分析。

更快地构建仪表板

传统上，构建 Grafana 仪表板通常意味着为每个面板编写一个新查询。现在，通过保存的查询，您可以从可重用查询库中提取数据并快速填充面板，这样您就可以将更多时间用于可视化数据，而减少编写代码的时间。

例如，团队可以为请求吞吐量、错误计数或缓存命中率等指标创建“基线查询库”。创建仪表板时，用户可以简单地从这些可信查询中进行选择。性能团队还可以整理“批准的查询”列表，标准化跨团队计算延迟、可用性或资源使用情况的方式，从而减少不匹配的定义。

改进入职培训和知识共享

并非每个人都是查询语言专家。例如，在 Explore 中编写 Grafana Loki 查询的团队通常必须编写涉及标签、正则表达式过滤器和速率函数的复杂 LogQL 表达式。 

通过保存的查询，高级用户可以保存经过充分测试的 LogQL 查询，例如每个服务的错误率或慢速请求日志的查询，以便其他人可以重复使用它们，而无需深入学习 LogQL。

这种知识共享也有利于故障排除工作流程。当事件发生时，响应人员只需打开“探索”并重复使用过去调查中保存的查询即可加快响应时间。

管理注释

在 Grafana 中，注释是一种在可视化中指示某些事件的方法，包括部署、功能发布或事件开始/结束时间。与保存的查询、注释变得更易于管理和重用。 

团队无需在每个仪表板上手动重新创建注释查询，而是可以保存单个查询（例如，用于标记部署的 Loki LogQL 表达式，如 {app="frontend", message=~"Deployment.*completed"} 或从指标中提取事件时间戳的 PromQL 查询）并在仪表板中重复使用。这可确保一致的事件覆盖，例如部署、中断或配置更改，同时简化非专家的设置并减少维护开销。

减少代价高昂的错误

不小心编写昂贵或低效的查询可能会减慢速度并影响利润。保存的查询允许查询语言专家提供可信的、优化的查询，其他人可以安全地重复使用。这可以降低风险并帮助团队在仪表板和探索会话之间保持一致的查询性能。

开始使用已保存的查询

与已保存查询功能交互的主要方式有两种：保存查询或使用已保存查询。 

如何保存查询

当您在查询编辑器中创建要保存的查询时，请点击保存查询。 

<图 类=“图包装图包装__lightbox w-100p” 样式=“最大宽度：无；” itemprop =“关联媒体” 项目范围=“” itemtype =“http://schema.org/ImageObject” ><一个 类=“灯箱链接” href="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/1999x616/b9b2f417a4/save-query-button.png/m/" itemprop=“内容网址” >
<无脚本> <图片 src =“https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/1999x616/b9b2f417a4/save-query-button.png/m/” alt="Grafana Cloud 界面的屏幕截图，显示查询编辑器和正在进行的查询。“保存查询”按钮以红色突出显示。"/>

这将打开已保存的查询抽屉，您可以在其中输入查询的标题、可选描述和标签。

<图 类=“图包装图包装__lightbox w-100p” 样式=“最大宽度：无；” itemprop =“关联媒体” 项目范围=“” itemtype =“http://schema.org/ImageObject” ><一个 类=“灯箱链接” href="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/1153x924/4405b4add8/saved-queries-title-description-and-tags.png/m/" itemprop=“内容网址” >
<无脚本> <图片 src="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/1153x924/4405b4add8/saved-queries-title-description-and-tags.png/m/" alt="“已保存查询”抽屉的屏幕截图，显示查询设置，其中包含标题、描述、标签、作者和日期字段。"/>

标签和详细描述有助于根据对您的组织有意义的主题对查询进行分组。这使得其他人可以轻松地通过可搜索列表找到与他们相关的查询。

您还可以为查询选择两个可见性选项：

  • 私人：这是默认设置，意味着只有您才能看到该查询。
  • 共享：当您希望组织内的其他用户可以看到查询时，请使用此设置。

如何使用已保存的查询

要访问您的队友已保存的其他查询，请在查询编辑器中点击+ 从已保存的查询添加。

这将再次打开已保存的查询抽屉，您可以在其中按数据源、作者或标签搜索和过滤查询。

<图 类=“图包装图包装__lightbox w-100p” 样式=“最大宽度：无；” itemprop =“关联媒体” 项目范围=“” itemtype =“http://schema.org/ImageObject” ><一个 类=“灯箱链接” href="https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/1146x929/f97feb9b2a/saved-queries-filter-by-tags.png/m/" itemprop=“内容网址” >
<无脚本> <图片 src =“https://a-us.storyblok.com/f/1022730/1146x929/f97feb9b2a/saved-queries-filter-by-tags.png/m/” alt="“已保存查询”抽屉的屏幕截图，显示 Grafana 日志记录的搜索和筛选选项、标签以及查询详细信息。"/>

请注意，当您将已保存的查询添加到面板或浏览时，查询内容会自动复制进来；如果该查询的作者最终对其进行了编辑，您将需要重新添加该查询。

您还可以创建最常引用的查询列表，并在收藏夹标签中快速找到它们。

总结

已保存的查询现已向所有 Grafana Cloud 用户提供公共预览版，并且还可以通过 queryLibrary 功能切换在 Grafana Enterprise 中启用。要了解有关如何保存、共享和管理查询的更多信息，请查看我们的文档。

展望未来，我们正在探索使已保存查询更加强大的方法，包括增强对参数化的支持查询、对警报规则的支持以及通过引用存储查询的能力，因此单个更改可以自动更新使用它的每个仪表板。

同时，当您开始使用已保存的查询时，我们很想听听您的想法。请填写已保存查询抽屉中的反馈表，分享您喜欢的内容以及我们可以改进的内容。您的反馈将有助于塑造此功能的未来！
